bestBHT.bht: In these dark days, men shall desperately yearn for death as they grapple with excruciating pain and misery, seeking relief that cannot be found. The anguish they face is so relentless and agonizing that they long to escape their suffering, but death eludes them. The intensity of their desire is profound, as they eagerly, yet futilely, pursue the respite of death. Their yearning reveals the depth of their torment, emphasizing that even death fails to bring the solace they desperately seek.

Henry Alford: And in those days men shall seek death, and shall not find it."
They shall vehemently desire to die, and death fleeth from them."
The longing to die arises from the excruciating pain of the sting.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: shall desire—Greek, 'eagerly desire'; set their mind on.
shall flee—So B, Vulgate, Syriac, and Coptic read.
In :-, which is at a later stage of God's judgments, the ungodly seek annihilation, not from the torment of their suffering, but from fear of the face of the Lamb before whom they have to stand.
Albert Barnes: It is a state where the distress is so great that people would consider death a relief, and where they anxiously look to the time when they may be released from their sufferings by death.

In cells and dungeons; on beds of pain and languishing; in scenes of poverty and want; in blighted hopes and disappointed affections, how many are there who would be glad to die, and who have no hope of an end of suffering but in the grave!
To a portion death will be a relief. It will be an end of sufferings. They will find peace in the grave, and are assured they shall suffer no more.
Marvin Vincent: Men. Rather, the men : those tormented.
Shall desire [επιθυμησουσιν] . Epi has the force of vehemently, earnestly.
Shall flee [φευξεται] . Read feugei fleeth. Aeschylus says : 'Not justly do mortals hate death, since it is the greatest deliverance from their many woes'.
Philip Schaff: So terrible is the plague that men shall eagerly, but in vain, desire to die."
This double reference must be considered as conclusive upon the point that Job is in the Apostle’s eye.
The locust-plague is demoniacal not earthly in its origin.
Archibald T. Robertson: Such a death as they desire, a death which will end their sufferings, is impossible; physical death is no remedy for the βασανισμος of an evil conscience.
They shall desire to die, a climax to ζητησουσιν (they shall seek), to desire vehemently.
Even death does not come to their relief.
John Gill: In those days men shall seek death, and shall not find it.
Death will be preferred to a miserable life; it will be chosen rather than life.
The ravages of the Saracens...made death more eligible to them than life.
John Wesley: The men — That is, the men who are so tormented.

bhtAttempts.bht: In these dark days, men shall desperately yearn for death as they grapple with excruciating pain and misery, seeking relief that cannot be found. The anguish they face is so relentless and agonizing that they long to escape their suffering, but death eludes them. The intensity of their desire is profound, as they eagerly, yet futilely, pursue the respite of death. Their yearning reveals the depth of their torment, emphasizing that even death fails to bring the solace they desperately seek.

In those days, men shall desperately seek death, but it shall evade them. Their profound desire is born out of the overwhelming pain inflicted upon them. They relentlessly yearn for the release death would bring, yet it remains elusive. Physical death cannot cure the anguish of their troubled consciences. Their vehement longing emphasizes the unbearable suffering they endure, magnifying the fact that even death cannot provide the respite they seek.

In those days, men shall desperately seek death and their longing to die arises from the excruciating pain they experience. Their earnest desire for death culminates in a fervent pursuit. However, death flees from them, denying them the relief they so desperately crave. It becomes evident that the torment they face is beyond the reach of physical death, as their suffering is rooted in an evil conscience. Even death, the greatest deliverance from worldly woes, cannot provide the respite they deeply desire.

In that time, men will passionately seek out death, fueled by the intense pain they endure. Their ardent longing for release drives them to relentlessly pursue it. However, death eludes them, refusing to bring an end to their suffering. Their deep yearning reveals the magnitude of their torment, showcasing how even death cannot provide the relief they desperately seek. Their desire for annihilation arises from the fear of facing the Lamb, as their evil conscience persists despite physical death.

In those days, a time of great distress, men shall vehemently desire death, yearning for it as a means to escape their excruciating pain. However, death shall flee from them, denying them relief. This intense longing to die is driven by the torment of their agonizing conscience, a suffering that cannot be alleviated by physical death. Even though death is typically seen as a deliverance from suffering, it becomes clear that the evil they face in their hearts cannot be resolved through mortality.
